Award.AwardTitle: IDBR: TYPE A: An Integrated Microfluidic Platform for Parallel Analysis of Cell Secretome and Cell Responses in Real Time
Award.AbstractNarration:
An award is made to the University of Akron to develop a novel microfluidic instrument for parallel analysis of proteins secreted from cells (secretomes) and cell responses to stimuli in real time, with high sensitivity and high throughput. Understanding the composition of proteins secreted from cells has broad impacts on cell biology and the understanding of cellular responses to stimuli, including cellular signaling pathways, intercellular communications, and matrix remodeling. The study of secretomes will also impact drug discovery and therapy development, which will lead to improved public health. The multidisciplinary nature of this project is expected to stimulate students' interest in state-of-the-art lab-on-a-chip devices and advanced biotechnology, and offer training opportunities for students to cross their discipline boundaries by learning new principles and methods. Through various student programs at University of Akron, undergraduate students will be recruited, with an emphasis on underrepresented minorities and women, to conduct research in this project. The developed methods and the instrument will be actively promoted to the biological research community via the collaborations with the Center for Stem Cell and Regenerative Medicine at Cleveland Clinic Foundation and the Northeast Ohio Center for Regenerative and Translational Medicine. Through working with NSF I-Corps site at the University of Akron Research Foundation, this instrument will be further developed and commercialization opportunity will be explored.

Thus far, conventional methods for cell secretome and cell response analysis require tedious procedures, long assay times, and bulky, complicated detection instruments. In addition, there is no existing instrument that can perform parallel assays of multiple cell secretions and responses in real time. In this project a microfluidic instrument consisting of a thermo-responsive culture chamber for rapid cell detachment without sample contamination, an innovative immuno-disaggregation assay for highly sensitive analysis of cell secretomes, and a label-free magnetic bead assay for analyzing various cell responses to stimuli will be developed to address the issues.. A multiplexed micro detection array will be used to enable high throughput, simultaneous measurements of cell secretomes and cell responses.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Rapid, onsite analysis of cell secretome and cell responses can reflect the state of the cells during morphogenesis, differentiation, injury, as well as disease progression, and thus critical information for fundamental and applied biology research, biomarker discovery and therapy development. For cell secretome analysis, conventional immunoassays such as enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) require labeling antibodies, long assay time, and bulky, complicated detection instruments. For cell response analysis, current methods (e.g. chemical, florescence and colorimetric methods) typically involve tedious procedures and cannot perform onsite assay.

With the funding from National Science Foundation, researchers at University of Akron have successfully demonstrated a novel microfluidic platform to analyze many stimuli-induced cell responses and secreted proteins with high throughout and high sensitivity. With this platform, cell responses (changes in viability, proliferation, metabolism, etc.) after stimuli are assessed using a novel magnetic bead (MB) cell assay, while secreted proteins by cells are analyzed by an innovative competitive immuno-disaggregation assay Both detection methods are label free, eliminate the need to chemically modify the surface of microchannels, and yet has high sensitivity and specificity, making it particularly suitable for onsite applications. The platform will be very useful for providing comprehensive information for cell development research, disease diagnosis and prognosis, and therapy strategy development. 

In terms of scientific impact, the compact and low cost device will advance basic understanding of cell development, functions and interactions, and how cells sense and respond to external stimuli at real time, which are required by bioengineering, developmental and cell biology, biomedical research, and applied bioagriculture and bioindustry. In particular, the instrument has broad impacts on secretomics, therapy development and drug discovery.  It is a powerful tool for secretomic analysis of cancer cell lines and diseased tissue, a simpler but more specific alternative to the conventional full serum proteomic method or other methods using a complex and highly variable body fluid.  In addition, the developed instrument can unveil the relationship between cell status and cell secretome profile, which will shed new light on cell regulation and cell signaling networks, and advance understandings of systems biology.

In terms of education and outreach, the research activities were highly multi-disciplinary, involving microfluidics, cell biology, biosensing, multiplexing, and provided educational experiences for the students and faculty members involved in the project. During the project, five graduate students and over 10 undergraduate students participated in the research. One high school students were involved in the research activities, who chose engineering as their major in college. Research results were included in two classes offered to graduate students and senior undergraduate students, and delivered to middle school girls during their summer visit.
